Award.AwardTitle: IDR: Collaborative Research: Novel Photonic Materials and Devices based on Non-Hermitian Optics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this proposal is to develop novel photonic devices and artificial materials-appropriately engineered to display properties not found in nature. A new approach that exploits the complex dielectric permittivity plane in its entirety will be employed. This will be achieved by judiciously controlling both absorption and gain-especially in integrated optical arrangements based on semiconductor wafers. To carry out this task, an interdisciplinary team composed of engineers, physicists, material scientists, and mathematicians with complementary skills and know-how has been assembled.

The intellectual merit of this activity is based on very recent developments in optics that make use of space-time reflection. The non-Hermitian potentials involved in such arrangements break the spatial symmetry, thus allowing a wave to distinguish left from right. This leads to non-reciprocal wave behavior in both space and time. The team will investigate: (i) non-reciprocal light propagation in linear and nonlinear non-Hermitian structures as a means to realize compact optical isolators and circulators; (ii) wavefront and energy propagation for on-chip beam deflectors; (iii) non-Hermitian absorbers and amplifiers by manipulating the propagation properties of light; and (iv) unidirectional invisibility induced by non-Hermitian gratings.

The broader impact of this work will be on educating students to drive tomorrow?s advancements in photonics. They will be trained in modeling, material growth, device fabrication, and optical characterization and through constant interactions with their peers at the partner institutions. The team will organize workshops to engage the photonics community at large in non-Hermitian optics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 1998, Bender and Boettcher found that a large class of non-Hermitian Hamiltonians can exhibit real spectra. Their discovery goes against intuition given that observables in quantum mechanical settings are by nature Hermitian. What was very interesting in this regard, was the possibility of phase transitions in such systems beyond which the spectrum ceases to be entirely real. These transitions were found to occur around non-Hermitian degeneracies better known as exceptional points. Remarkably, around such degeneracies not only the eigenvalues tend to coalesce but so do the corresponding eigenvectors. In this case, there is a sudden collapse in vector space dimensionality. Few years ago, our group suggested to explore for the first time, the ramifications of parity-time symmetry in optical settings. From a physical perspective, this could be accomplished by judiciously intermixing optical gain and loss as a means to synthesize novel structures, devices and materials with desired properties and functionalities – not easily attainable in standard settings.

 

In 2012, our team in collaboration with the university of Erlangen observed for the first time light transport in PT-synthetic photonic lattices (Nature 488, 167 (2012)). In this work, we experimentally demonstrated temporally resolved optical beam dynamics in large-scale PT-symmetric looped arrays. A schematic of such a configuration where PT-symmetric effects can occur is shown in Fig. 1. The unusual band structure associated with such extended systems was probed along with power unfolding and secondary emissions resulting from the skewed character of the Floquet–Bloch modes. In addition, we observed unidirectional invisibility in PT-symmetric temporal gratings when operated close to the system’s exceptional points. The reflectivity of these structures was found to strongly depend on the direction of propagation in these settings.

In subsequent experiments, in this same fiber-loop platform, we observed optical soliton transport (Nature Communications 6, 7782 (2015)) as well as non-Hermitian defect states capable of existing even in the band structure of the system. In addition, we presented the first experimental observation of Bloch oscillations in parity-time-symmetric mesh lattices (Scientific Reports 5, 17760 (2015)). In this regard, we showed that Bloch revivals exhibit unusual properties like secondary emissions and resonant restoration of PT symmetry. In 2014, our team also demonstrated that PT symmetry breaking can be elegantly exploited to establish single-mode operation in inherently multimoded microring lasers (Science 346, 975 (2014)). This was accomplished in a coupled arrangement of two structurally identical ring resonators, with one experiencing gain while the other provides an equal amount of loss (see Fig. 2). The key idea behind this mechanism is that the threshold of symmetry breaking depends solely on the relation between gain/loss and coupling. Whereas any active resonator can generally display single-wavelength operation when the pump power is reduced, selective breaking of PT symmetry can be used to systematically enhance the maximum attainable gain of this mode. This is possible even if a large number of competing longitudinal or transverse resonator modes fall within the amplification bandwidth of the inhomogeneously broadened active medium. Consequently, our approach naturally exhibited a type of broadband self-adaptive behavior and is, in principle, applicable to any active resonator configuration.

During the course of this project, we have also explored several other topics. These include for example, the possibility for supersymmetry in optics and photonics, supersymmetric transformation optics and mode converters, as well as prospects for constant intensity waves in strongly non-Hermitian environments. Our work could pave the way towards new structures and devices based on non-Hermitian concepts such as that of parity-time symmetry.
